def: something that is unusual or unexpected
sent: The student’s poor performance on the latest test was an anomaly since she had previously earned excellent grades.

def: not easily understood or explained
sent: Politicians have been known to provide equivocal answers to reporters’ questions.

def: very clear and easy to understand
sent: The lecture was lucid and straightforward, allowing the students to fully grasp the concepts presented.

def: to cause (something) to happen quickly or suddenly
sent: Unforeseen costs can precipitate a budget crisis

def: to make (an unpleasant feeling) less intense
sent: A massage can assuage the soreness in your muscles.

def: having or showing great knowledge
sent: High school students often struggle with novels that are more erudite than they are entertaining.

def: wastefully extravagant
sent: The prodigal prince bought lavish gifts and planned expensive events.

def: a person or thing that is mysterious, puzzling, or difficult to understand
sent: Scientists continue to research cancer to solve the enigmaof its primary cause, which will hopefully lead to a cure.

def: intensely enthusiastic or passionate
sent: The child showed a fervid fascination for superheroes, pouring over comic books for hours.

def: a willingness to take bold risks / adj. –  showing a lack of respect
sent: The new CEO pursued audacious initiatives to save the company from bankruptcy. / The student’s audaciousremark earned her a seat in afternoon detention.

def: remove the moisture from (something)
sent: The heat and energy from the sun can desiccate even the most hearty plants

def: deserving praise and commendation
sent: Providing affordable healthcare for all citizens is a laudablegoal.

def: a person who makes an excessive display of learning
sent: Professor Blackwell, a well-known pedant, required his pre-med students to speak in Latin throughout the entire semester.

def: to waver between different opinions or actions
sent: Undergraduate students often vacillate among various majors before deciding which degree to pursue.

def: to make (something) impure or weaker by adding something of inferior quality
sent: Many chefs use fresh produce and refuse to adulteratetheir dishes with canned ingredients.

def: given to sudden changes of mood or behavior
sent: The capricious supervisor would hand out raises one day and fire his entire staff the next.

def: to produce, cause, or give rise to (something)
sent: Political debates can engender controversy regarding the subjects discussed.

def: tending to talk a great deal
sent: The loquacious professor was known for his five-hour lectures.

def: dealing with the problems that exist in a reasonable and logical way instead of depending on theories
sent: A pragmatic approach to legislation can be difficult given the complexities of politics.

def: likely to change rapidly and unpredictably
sent: It is possible for a country’s political climate to remain volatile for decades.

def: to confirm or make more certain
sent: The scientist was able to corroborate his hypothesis with data gathered from multiple sources.

def: lasting for a very short time
sent: An ephemeral moment of victory may last mere seconds, but it can remain as a triumphant memory for decades.

def: using few words
sent: The student’s laconic response suggested  that she did not know very much about the topic the professor was discussing.

def: the state or quality of being correct or proper
sent: The students were instructed to behave with the utmost propriety while on their class field trip.

def: a harsh, unpleasant mixture of sounds
sent: The cacophony of the middle school band warming up was nearly unbearable for the audience.

def: cause (someone or something) to feel drained of energy; weaken
sent: The boxer used a swift left uppercut to the jaw to enervatehis opponent.

def: a person who dislikes humankind
sent: The neighborhood misanthrope surrounded his yard with barbed wire to keep people away.

def: regard with great respect
sent: To venerate the fire chief’s forty years of service, the department held a special banquet.

def: to express contempt for; ridicule
sent: The unreasonable supervise was known to deride his employees on a daily basis.

def: stubbornly refusing to change one’s opinion
sent: The obdurate three-year-old refused to eat any vegetables, no matter how they were prepared.

def: a lack of harmony or agreement
sent: The school board’s meeting lasted for hours due to the length debate fueled by dissonance among opinions.

def: excessively talkative
sent: The garrulous hair stylist talked to each customer for hours at a time.

def: excessive display of wealth
sent: Owning a mansion doesn’t imply ostentation, but traveling exclusively by private jet certainly can.

def: avoid telling the truth by not directly answering a question
sent: During the trial, the lead witness was willing to prevaricatein order to protect his friend.

def: a thing formed or added by gradual growth or increase.
sent: The city has a historic core surrounded by recent accretions.

def: the pursuit of pleasure; sensual self-indulgence.
sent: She was a perfect specimen of selfish hedonism.

def: a remedy for all ills or difficulties / cure-all
sent: The law will improve the lives of local farmers, but it is no panacea.

def: affectedly dainty or delicate
sent: She took mincing steps.

def: to become diffused throughout every part of
sent: A feeling of great sadness pervades the film.

def: to reduce in vigor or intensity or impurities. ALSO to make improvement by introducing subtleties or distinctions.
sent: The inventor of the machine spent years refining the design.

def: affected by strong feelings of love, admiration, or fascination
sent: Japanese fans took to the gruff Americans, but the homegrown players were less enamored.

def: the act of blaming or condemning sternly or reprimanding
sent: The country faces international censure for its alleged involvement in the assassination.

def: to voice disapproval of
sent: Without exception, book reviewers reprehended the novel's tired plot.

def: mental acceptance as true or real
sent: Some members of my family give credence to gossip.

def: outwardly similar or corresponding to something without having its genuine qualities, deceitful
sent: The spurious eminence of the pop celebrity was revealed by the lackluster Spotify listens.

def: an extremely confused, complicated, or embarrassing situation.
sent: California considers the 2016 Election to be America's imbroglio.

def: involved with others in an illegal activity or wrongdoing.
sent: All of these people are complicit in some criminal conspiracy.

def: rapid increase in numbers.
sent: "You left the raw chicken out. Thank of the proliferation of salmonella!"

def: the action or practice of acting as if one were morally superior to other people.
sent: They have no shame and turn on the phony sanctimony

def: criticize in an abusive or angrily insulting manner.
sent: "After the impeachment, Bill Clinton is now reviled by the party that he had helped to lead."

def: entertain or amuse (someone) with talk / lavishly supply (someone) with food or drink.
sent: Ariel regaled everyone at her Sweet 16 party.

def: (of a person or their behavior) primarily concerned with making money at the expense of ethics.
sent: Insurance premiums are very very high for mercenaries.

def: (of a phrase or idea) lacking significance through having been overused; unoriginal and trite.
sent: Some teachers give you an auto-F if you include any cliches or a hackneyed thesis.

def: friendly and cheerful.
sent: Kerry is constantly genial, welcoming everyone with a smile and big hello.

def: having or showing a tendency to be easily angered.
sent: It's very hard for me to be friends with someone who is irascible and not getting help.

def: friendly, good-natured, or easy to talk to.
sent: Esther's affable nature is the first thing that I notice in the dining hall.

def: bad-tempered or irritable.
sent: I am most choleric when I feel sick from anxiety.

def: quiet, gentle, and easily imposed on; submissive.
sent: "I used to call her Miss Mouse because she was so meek and mild"

def: (especially of fabric) light, delicate, and translucent.
sent: A diaphanous dress of pale gold draped the woman on the Paris catwalk.

def: deviating from what is standard, normal, or expected.
sent: Smith College has an anomalous student culture.

def: overly theatrical or melodramatic in character or style / exaggerated dramatic behavior designed to attract attention.
sent: Histrionic people want attention but I can't stop thinking about how much of my time they're wasting.

def: (of a person) having an unemotional and stolidly calm disposition.
sent: My dad is extremely phlegmatic, even outside of pollen season.

def: (of a person) tending to show feelings, especially of affection, openly. conclusive evidence.
sent: Many love songs are over-the-top demonstrative.

def: showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense.
sent: Forrest Gump had vehement love and dedication to Jenny.

def: excessively sweet or sentimental.
sent: I wrote a saccharine jar of comliments. I almost regret it.

def: to bring into discord or conflict; involve in contention or strife / to throw into confusion; complicate.
sent: Group work during summer linear algebra day 2 was embroiling.

def: a speech or piece of writing that praises someone or something highly.
sent: You get a eulogy if you die but a encomium if you're still kicking.

def: a public speech or published text in praise of someone or something.
sent: A NYT panegyric on friendship was heartwarming to many childhood buddies.

def: the dwelling of a hermit, especially when small and remote.
sent: If I live in Los Angeles after college, I'll live with my mom or my own hermitage.

def: to charge with wrong-doing; accuse
sent: I accused Michael Jones with manslaughter in the second degree.

def: nitpicky
sent: I am most relived when I am done with a fastidious teacher and class.

def: 1. Changing one’s personality often and unpredictably. 2. Animated, sprightly
sent: Mercurial friends are exhausting to be around, especially when I feel tired.

def: big-hearted; generous
sent: Hagrid was the magnanimous groundskeeper for Harry, Ron and Hermione.

def: to weaken; drain the energy from
sent: The sun enervated Sarah just five minutes into the hike.

def: favorable
sent: Clear skies today are auspicious for a turbulance-free flight.

def: inducing sleep
sent: I had too much caffine today and so I put on the soporific lavender diffuser.

def: known to a select few
sent: While the location of the national treasure was esoteric; the blockbuster movie is not.

def: a state of temporary disuse or suspension
sent: Put your belief in physics into abeyance - let me introduce you to a perpetual motion machine.

def: solemnly renounce (a belief, cause, or claim)
sent: Abjure your Republican loyalty - Trump's new tax plan actually increased your taxes.

def: not likely to cause offence or disagreement and somewhat dull
sent: Find a balance between incessent political rants and anodyne commentary.

def: obtain or withhold money from (someone) by deceit or without justification
sent: Be careful of scam artists bilking you as you travel this summer.

def: an unfounded rumor or story
sent: It's harder to learn what is true or canard in the Trump administration.

def: (in a legislative assembly) a procedure for ending a debate and taking a vote
sent: My friends have taken so long debating today's plans that we need to move to cloture or run out of daylight.

def: a collection of concise but detailed information about a particular subject
sent: Wikipedia is the most excellent compendium so far in the history of humankind.

def: enlist (someone) compulsorily
sent: I conscripted my friends to help move my couch.

def: care for and protect in an overindulgent way
sent: Helicopter parents both over-punish and cosset their offspring.

def: a small group of people with shared interests or tastes
sent: Michelle is excited for her knitting coterie on Meetup.

def: a person who cultivates an area of interest without real commitment or knowledge
sent: Pick your major with purpose - absolutely do not be a dilettante.

def: (Of animals) active in the daytime
sent: I would be diurnal if I didn't work the nightshift at 7/11.

def: something regarded as worthless
sent: My dad believes anything other than a SEM major is dross.

def: cheerful and full of energy
sent: The 4th grader felt ebullient now that her bully switched schools.

def: instruct or improve (someone) morally or intellectually
sent: Attend college to edify and learn words like "edify."

def: (of a product) used as a substitute, typically an inferior one, for something else
sent: Bubbly water has indistingushable generics but ice cream has many ersatz.

def: former
sent: The erstwhile owner of the Taco Deli resturant is now enjoying her retirement.

def: atone for (guilt or sin)
sent: My dad is always expiating or building up God Points (TM).

def: still in existence; surviving
sent: Pasadena Historic Registery accepts anything  as young as 50 years because there are few impressive extant buildings.

def: a noisy disturbance or quarrel
sent: A cat fracas woke me up the other night.

def: a series of shots fired or missiles thrown all at the same time or in quick succession
sent: Fusillade is not allowed at the shooting range. You have to take your time.

def: blunder, mistake, error
sent: Usually a gaffe knocks primary candidates out of the running, with the soundbite circulating for weeks.

def: speak against or oppose (someone)
sent: In a workplace you have to be very polite and political when if you gainsay anyone.

def: a state, society, or group governed by old people
sent: I thought the Republican party was a gerontocracy but they are gaining more college-age voters who want to be counter-culture.

def: denoting a period of time in the past that was idyllically happy and peaceful
sent: The Obama Administration appears comparatively halcyon.

def: insulated or protected from outside influences
sent: Censorship typically leads to a populace with unoriginal and hermetic beliefs.

def: not conforming with accepted or orthodox standards or beliefs
sent: Among those discriminated against for holding heterodox religious views, the Bahai community continues particularly to suffer.

def: a person who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
sent: The iconoclast goverment during the October and February Revolutions destroyed a majority of religious instituions.

def: an extremely happy, peaceful, or picturesque episode or scene
sent: A idyll vacation is ideal to me.

def: dispute the truth, validity, or honesty of (a statement or motive)
sent: Many news organizations impugn trump's claim about a larger audience than Obama's inaugeration.

def: a cause of distress or anxiety
sent: I appreciate my single room to avoid an incubus of a roommate.

def: the sound of a bell, especially when rung solemnly for a death or funeral
sent: At 3pm on the dot, my linear algebra class started with a knell.

def: sad, tearful, weepy
sent: The series finale of Parks and Rec was both happy and lachrymose.

def: interval, gap
sent: The teacher froze at the lacuna in her student roster during an earthquake drill.

def: criticize (someone or something) harshly
sent: I don't need to be lectured on my bad grade. I lambaste myself already.

def: theft of personal property
sent: If you swipe that from the 7/11 you'll be charged with larceny.

def: a person who rejects accepted opinions in matters of religion
sent: Organized religion makes my spine shiver - I'm a libertine.

def: looking or sounding sad and dismal
sent: The dingy patio chairs looked lugubrious after spending all winter in the rain.

def: a situation or state of confused movement or violent turmoil
sent: Post-2016, American politics are maelstrom as each party figures out its game theory.

def: a wealthy and influential businessman or businesswoman
sent: Some magnates made their fortunes by making a product for people whose needs are typically forgotten.

def: the mistaken use of a word in place of a similar-sounding one, often with unintentionally amusing effect
sent: Unintentional puns are a type of malaproprism.

def: large, powerful, and intractably indivisible and uniform
sent: I boycot Nestle, the monolithic company.

def: larger or more generous than is usual or necessary
sent: Inflated undergrad prices have made munificent scholarships increasingly rare.

def: short-sighted, insular, small-minded
sent: Being cheap is myopic because sometimes you need to buy something to last.

def: the lowest point in the fortunes of a person or organization
sent: Between its pre-crisis peak in late 2007 and its nadir at the end of 2009, the economy contracted by 11.2%

def: a person who is new to a subject, skill, or belief
sent: Mr. Gioia also delves into musical theory, in a way that will help both jazz neophytes and experts understand what they are listening to.

def: having an extremely offensive smell
sent: The skunk's noisome substance irritated my nose.

def: a pet scheme or favorite remedy, especially one for bringing about some social or political reform or improvement
sent: The Republican's nostrum is to constantly call for lower taxes.

def: stop, close up, or obstruct
sent: Mars will be as far away as 370m kilometres in 2013, and occluded for two weeks by the sun.

def: a song of praise or triumph
sent: He got a paean after the war and a eulogy when he died his wounds two weeks later.

def: a complete or impressive collection of things
sent: He called it his panoply. I called it clutter.

def: an artistic work consisting of a medley of pieces taken from various sources
sent: All the Girl Scouts made a pastiche out of craft supplies I found in the back of the storage closet.

def: the presence of something only in small or insufficient quantities or amounts
sent: The three-legged dog has a paucity of paws.

def: lucid in style or meaning; easily understood
sent: These GRE words are absolutely not pellucid.

def: a body of troops or police officers standing or moving in close formation
sent: A collection of giant slabs surrounded by thick iron railings, protected by a phalanx of armed guards.

def: a person who is hostile or indifferent to culture and the arts
sent: The philistine constnatly voted to defund libraries and museums.

def: a feeling of irritation or resentment resulting from a slight
sent: The man held onto the pique, refusing to accept it could've been a miscommunication.

def: a strong verbal or written attack on someone or something
sent: It's easy to write a polemic online without considering your harshness or tone.

def: a summary or abstract of a text or speech
sent: I confess that I usually only read the précis rather than the full academic article.

def: ordinary, everyday
sent: I found a kitten. Nothing special, just a prosaic housecat.

def: childishly silly and trivial
sent: Some consider dinosaur-shaped  chicken nuggets puerile.

def: an expert in a particular subject or field who is frequently called on to give opinions about it to the public
sent: Caltech has their earthquake pundit.

def: complaining in a petulant or whining manner
sent: Their querulous, hostile or annoyed faces recur in her work from the late 1950s.

def: a state or period of inactivity or dormancy
sent: Getting sick led to the quiescence of my summer.

def: exceedingly idealistic; unrealistic and impractical
sent: I can't stand listening to her quixotic opinions any longer.

def: a person who tells anecdotes in a skillful and amusing way
sent: The raconteur in my 1st period class told elaborate lies about having 60 tabby cats.

def: remedy or compensation for a wrong or grievance
sent: The disappointing redress for the scratch on my car was rubbing it off with some saliva.

def: feast, banquet
sent: Don't overeat at your Thanksgiving repast.

def: Referring to sexual matters in an amusingly rude or irreverent way
sent: When challenged... about human rights in Chechnya, he replied with a ribald offer to arrange for the questioner's Islamic circumcision.

def: a tiny trace or spark of a specified quality or feeling
sent: After a scintilla of regret over lost youth, to turn 50 should be to enter the prime of life, with a plenitude of projects and achievements.

def: a person’s nickname
sent: This provoked widespread debate about the role of intellectual property and earned him the sobriquet 'Champion of Patents.

def: failing to act as a result of moral weakness or indolence
sent: Last year Shinzo Abe, the prime minister, brought in a corporate-governance code which...requires hitherto supine institutional investors to keep a close eye on firms they invest in.

def: act in an obsequious way
sent: Britain’s Conservative government is accused of sacrificing the steel industry to toady up to China.

def: Eager or quick to argue or fight
sent: I wanted to beg the truculent man to "calm down" but I thought it would make him more angry.

def: (of language or style) tediously pompous or bombastic
sent: It promotes a cult of personality around Mr. Baghdadi. It churns out turgid propaganda about repaired bridges and newly opened schools.

def: a beginner or novice
sent: When he was a young tyro in Silicon Valley, his libertarian vision inspired many of his business decisions.

def: Offense or annoyance
sent: Petro Poroshenko, Ukraine’s president, takes umbrage at charges that reforms are lagging.

def: Find fault with (someone)
sent: In the past its neighbours isolated and upbraided Austria for its flirtations with nationalist extremism.

def: (of countryside) green with grass or other rich vegetation
extremely severe or harmful in its effects
sent: Meningis B causes virulent brain damage while it kills you.

def: Destroy or impair the legal validity of
sent: A Modesto straight pride group claimed "We're a totally peaceful racist group," which vitiated their permit request.

def: Cruel and bitter criticism
sent: You can correct someone without vitriol.

def: blatant, clamorous, noisy
sent: I couldn't stand the vociferous Chuck E. Cheese parties.

def: a large number of items in no order; a confused mass
sent: I had a junk bin with a welter of desk items.

def: sift out, filter out
sent: California miners winnowed the gold from the river silt.
